list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Consider the function $f(x)=2x+k3x+4​$.


Write down the domain of $f$ in terms of $k$. [1]



Find $f−1(x)$ in terms of $k$. [2]



Hence write down the value of $k$ such that $f(x)$ is a self-inverse function.[1]
list.markScheme:
A rational function is undefined when the denominator is equal to zero.
$$$2x+kx​=0=−2k​​$$$
Any other value for $x$ is valid.
Hence we get the domain
$$$​x∈R,x=−2k​​​A1​$$$


We are trying to find the function $y=f−1(x)$.
The definition of an inverse states that
$$$(f∘f−1)(x)​=x​$$$
Hence we can rewrite this to get
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)​=x=x​$$$
Hence we get
$$$f(y)2y+k3y+4​​=x=x​$$$
Recall, we want $y=f−1(x)$ therefore we should rearrange this to make $y$ the subject.
$$$x(2y+k)2xy+kx​=3y+4=3y+4​$$$
To isolate $y$, we move all of the $y$ terms to one side and then factorise out $y$.
$$$2xy−3yy(2x−3)y​=−kx+4=−kx+4=2x−3−kx+4​f−1(x)=2x−3−kx+4​​​(M1)A1​$$$


A self-inverse function is such that $f(x)≡f−1(x)$.
Therefore
$$$2x+k3x+4​​≡2x−3−kx+4​​$$$
Comparing either the numerators or denominators,
$$$3x+4​=−kx+4​$$$
Therefore
$$$​k=−3​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Consider the function $f(x)=b+x+a4​$, $$ where $a,b∈Z$.
The equation of the vertical asymptote of $f(x)$ is $x=2$ and $f(32​)=0$.


Write down the value of $a$.[1]



Hence, find the value of $b$. [3]



Hence, write down the equation of the horizontal asymptote.[1]
list.markScheme:
The vertical asymptote occurs when the denominator of the fraction is equal to zero.
$$$2+a​=0a=−2​​A1​$$$


From the information given we know that the point $(32​,0)$ lies on the curve.
Hence, we can create an equation and solve it for $b$.
$$$0b​=b+32​−24​=−−34​4​b=3​​M1A1A1​$$$


The horizontal asymptote occurs as $x→±∞$. We can see that as this happens the fractional part of $f(x)$ will tend to $0$.
Hence the equation of the horizontal asymptote is
$$$y​=3+±∞−24​y=3​​A1​$$$
The answer must be given as an equation, either $y=3$ or $f(x)=3$.

$$$x→±∞lim​f(x)2a​​=2=2​$$$

$$$f(1)2+104+b​4+b​=−121​=−121​=−1​$$$

Solving the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we have
$$$2x−53x+4​3x+4x​=0=0=−34​​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are $(−34​,0)​$


Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we have
$$$y​=f(0)=2(0)−53(0)+4​=−54​​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the $y$-intercept are $(0,−54​)​$






We have
$$$x→±∞lim​f(x)​=23​​$$$
Hence the equation of the horizontal asymptote is $y=23​​$


We have
$$$[denominator of f]2x−5x​=0=0=25​​$$$
Hence the equation of the vertical asymptote is $x=25​​$




If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, we have

We have
$$$y​=2x−53x+4​[where y=f(x)]​$$$
Therefore
$$$xx(2y−5)2xy−5x2xy−3yy(2x−3)y​=2y−53y+4​[where y=f−1(x)]=3y+4=3y+4=5x+4=5x+4=2x−35x+4​f−1(x)=2x−35x+4​​​$$$


Sketching $f(x)$ and $f−1(x)$ on the same axes, we can find the points of intersection using the G.D.C.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9bb89137-6a40-482f-8a89-a20425dad3b5/images/897ceffb-d901-4e38-a2bb-f444d24cc122/aa1013b.PNG)




The midpoint of AB is given by
$$$(2x1​+x2​​,2y1​+y2​​)​=(2−0.45+4.45​,2−0.45+4.45​)=(2,2)​$$$
Point A and point B both lie on the line $y=x$, which has gradient $m=1$. Therefore the perpendicular bisector has gradient $m=−1$.
The equation of the perpendicular bisector is given by
$$$y−y1​y−2​=m(x−x1​)=−(x−2)y=−x+4​​$$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Let $f(x)=x+15​$, for $x=−1$.

For the graph of $f$, find:


the $x$-intercept;


the $y$-intercept;


the equation of the vertical asymptote. [5]





Let $g(x)=x−3$, for $x∈R$. The graphs of $f$ and $g$
intersect at points A and B.


Find the coordinates of A and B. [5]



Find the equation of the straight line that passes through
A and B,
giving your answer in the form $y=mx+c$. [3]



Write down the gradient of the line that is perpendicular
to the line
passing through A and B. [2]
list.markScheme:
Since the equation $f(x)=0$ has no solutions, there are
$no x-intercepts​$


Evaluating $f(x)=x+15​$ for $x=0$, we have
$$$f(0)​=0+15​=5​$$$
Hence the $y$-intercept is
$P(0,5)​$


We have
$$$x+1x​=0=0=−1​$$$
Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$x=−1​$




Solving the equation $f(x)=g(x)$ for $x$, we have
$$$x+15​5500x​=x−3=(x+1)(x−3)=x2−2x−3=x2−2x−8=(x+2)(x−4)=−2,4​$$$
Evaluating $g(x)=x−3$
for $x=−2$ and $x=4$, we find
$$$yy​==​g(−2)g(4)​==​−51​$$$
Hence we find
$A(−2,−5)​$
and
$B(4,1)​$


Using the gradient formula with A$(−2,−5)$ and B$(4,1)$, we have
$$$mAB​​=x2​−x1​y2​−y1​​=4−(−2)1−(−5)​=1​$$$
Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
A$(−2,−5)$ and $m=1$, we get
$$$y−y1​y−(−5)y+5​=m(x−x1​)=(1)(x−(−2))=x+2​$$$
$$$y=x−3​$$$


$m⊥AB​=−1​$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Sketch the curve $y=−​x−25​​$ and line
$y=−x−4$ on the same axes,
clearly indicating any $x$ and $y$ intercepts and any asymptotes.
[3]



Find the exact solutions to the equation $x+4=∣x−2∣5​$.
[5]
list.markScheme:
Let $f(x)=−​x−25​​$ where $x∈R$,
$x=2$.
Since $f(x)<0$ for all $x∈R$, $x=2$, the curve
$y=f(x)$ has no $x$-intercepts.
Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we obtain
$$$y​=f(0)=−​−25​​=−25​​$$$
Hence the point A$(0,−5/2)$ is the
$y$-intercept of the curve $y=f(x)$.
We have
$$$x→±∞lim​f(x)=0$$$
Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal asymptote of the curve
$y=f(x)$.
The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x=2$. Hence the line $x=2$
is a vertical asymptote of the curve $y=f(x)$.
The $x$ and $y$ intercepts of the line $y=−4−x$ are B$(−4,0)$ and
C$(0,−4)$.
If we sketch the curve $y=f(x)$ and line $y=−x−4$ on the same
axes, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3ce10e6d-6009-49da-a002-42ae1d773968/images/2248acaa-10a6-4043-b8a6-84823cf01ad6/38ce371d4e9621963b29074adf6413c8b9f71c7c.svg)




If we solve the equation $x+4=∣x−2∣5​$ for $x<2$, we
find
$$$x+4(x+4)(x−2)x2+2x−8x2+2x−3(x+3)(x−1)x​=−x−25​[since x−2<0]=−5=−5=0=0=−3,1​$$$
If we simplify the equation
$x+4=∣x−2∣5​$ for $x>2$, we have
$$$x+4(x+4)(x−2)x2+2x−8x2+2x−13​=x−25​[since x−2>0]=5=5=0​$$$
Hence, using the quadratic
formula, we find
$$$x​=2−2+22−4(1)(−13)​​[since x>2]=2−2+214​​=−1+14​​$$$
Hence the
exact solutions to the equation $x+4=∣x−2∣5​$ are  $−3,1,−1+14​​$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined by $f(x)=1+x+34x​$, for
$x=−3$.


Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, indicating clearly any asymptotes
and
points of intersection with the $x$ and $y$ axes. [4]



Find an expression for $f−1$. [4]



Find all values of $x$ for which $f(x)=f−1(x)$. [3]



Solve the inequality $∣f(x)∣<2$. [4]



Solve the inequality $f(∣x∣)<2$. [2]
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$1+x+34x​x+35x+3​5x+3x​=0=0=0=−53​​$$$
Hence the point
P$(−3/5,0)$ is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we obtain
$$$y​=f(0)=1​$$$
Hence the point Q$(0,1)$ is the $y$-intercept of
the graph of $y=f(x)$.
We have
$$$x→±∞lim​f(x)​=1+14​=5​$$$
Hence the line $y=5$ is a horizontal asymptote
of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x=−3$. Hence the line
$x=−3$
is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
If we sketch of the graph of $y=f(x)$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b02f9456-fc87-4d72-8046-b8ad6f17fd88/images/80e5d1bc-25e1-48da-ad0b-cf11c4df076c/a4ee5024679811f4302b4cf52d17f68170c60827.svg)




If we solve the equation $(f∘f−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=f−1(x)$, we find
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)​=x=x​$$$
$$$1+y+34y​y+35y+3​5y+3(5−x)yy​=x=x=xy+3x=3x−3=5−x3x−3​​$$$
Hence an expression for
$f−1$ is
$f−1(x)=5−x3x−3​​$


If we solve the equation $f(x)=f−1(x)$ for $x$, we get
$$$f(x)1+x+34x​x+35x+3​(5x+3)(5−x)25x−5x2+15−3x−8x2+16x+24​=f−1(x)=5−x3x−3​=5−x3x−3​=(3x−3)(x+3)=3x2+9x−3x−9=0​$$$
$$$x2−2x−3(x+1)(x−3)​=0=0​$$$
$$$x=−1,3​$$$


We have
$$$−2f−1(−2)​<<​∣f(x)∣f(x)x​<<<​22f−1(2)[since f−1(f(x))=x]​​$$$
Evaluating $y=f−1(x)$ for $x=−2$,
we get
$$$f−1(−2)​=5−(−2)3(−2)−3​=−79​​$$$
Evaluating $y=f−1(x)$ for
$x=2$, we obtain
$$$f−1(2)​=5−23(2)−3​=1​$$$
Hence the set of solutions to the inequality
$∣f(x)∣<2$ is
$−79​<x<1​$


If we solve the inequality $f(∣x∣)<2$ for $∣x∣$, we get
$$$1+∣x∣+34∣x∣​∣x∣+34∣x∣​4∣x∣3∣x∣∣x∣​<2<1<∣x∣+3<3<1​$$$
Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $f(∣x∣)<2$ is
$−1<x<1​$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined as $f(x)=x−2x2−(a+3)x+3a​$, where $x∈R,x=2$.
The parameter $a$ can be any real number.


For this part of the question $a=4$.


Find the equations of the vertical and oblique asymptotes of $f(x)$.


Justify that $f$ has two stationary points. Note: you do not need to find the coordinates of these points.


Hence, sketch $f(x)$ and identify the asymptotes and axis intercepts.[9]





Show that $f(x)$ will always have at least one root for any value of $a$. [3]



Find the range of values of $a$ for which $f$ has no stationary points. [4]



Show that the root of the equation of the oblique asymptote is always exactly 1 unit away from one of the roots of $f(x)$. [4]
list.markScheme:
The vertical asymptote occurs when the denominator is equal to zero
$$$x−2x​=0=2​$$$
Therefore the equation of the vertical asymptote is $x=2​$.
$$$A1$$$
$gap$
To find the oblique asymptote we use algebraic long division
$$$M1$$$
$gap$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/be5cd178-0dee-44aa-b522-868d3d4ac407/images/19c6b701-8702-4bc6-acd7-6845beb54d0c/a1040-1.png)


Using this result we can rewrite $f(x)$
$$$f(x)​=x−5+x−22​​$$$
We can see that as $x$ tends to positive or negative infinity $f(x)$ tends to $x−5$.
Therefore the equation of the oblique asypmpote is $y=x−5​$.
$$$A1$$$
$gap$


To find stationary points we need to solve the equation $f′(x)=0$. Using the quotient rule we find
$$$f′(x)​=(x−2)2(2x−7)(x−2)−(1)(x2−7x+12)​=(x−2)2)2x2−7x−4x+14−x2+7x−12)​=(x−2)2x2−4x+2​​M1A1​$$$
By solving $f′(x)=0$ we form a quadratic equation
$$$x2−4x+2​=0​$$$
The discriminant of the equation is
$$$(−4)2−4(1)(2)​=8>0​A1​$$$
The discriminant is greater than zero,
therefore$f(x) has two stationary points​$.


To find the $y−$intercepts we evaluate $f(0)=−212​$, therefore the $y−$axis intercept occurs at $(0,−6)$
For the $x−$intercepts we solve $f(x)=0$. Hence $(x−3)(x−4)=0$, the $x−$intercepts occur at $(3,0)$ and $(4,0)$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/be5cd178-0dee-44aa-b522-868d3d4ac407/images/704506d7-2edd-45f7-b7c0-09049d21fab7/AA1040new.png)

We must show that the equation $f(x)=0$ has at least one solution for all values of $a$. For that we can find the discriminant of the numerator
$$$△​=(−(a+3))2−4(1)(3a)=a2+6a+9−12a=a2−6a+9=(a−3)2​M1A1​$$$
As $(a−3)2≥0$ for all values of $a$ then
$$$A1$$$

$f(x) will always have at least one root.​$


Find the derivative of $f(x)$ using the quotient rule
$$$f′(x)​=(x−2)2(2x−(a+3))(x−2)−(1)(x2−(a+3)x+3a)​=(x−2)22x2−4x−ax​+2a−3x​+6−x2+ax​+3x​−3a​=(x−2)2x2−4x−a+6​​(A1)​$$$
We must find the range of values of $a$ for which there are no solutions to the equation $f′(x)=0$. We can find the discriminant of the numerator found above
$$$△​=(−4)2−4(1)(6−a)=4a−8​(M1)​$$$
Therefore there are no solutions to $f′(x)=0$ when $4a−8<0$, so we have no stationary points for $a<2$.
$$$A1$$$

Also, when $a=2$, we have
$$$f′(x)​=(x−2)2x2−4x+4​=(x−2)2(x−2)2​=1​$$$
Hence when $a=2$, we have a constant gradient of $1$, and $f(x)$ is a linear function (with a hole at $x=2$) and hence has no stationary point.
Hence $f$ has no stationary points for $a≤2​.$

The root of the oblique asymptote occurs when $y=0$, therefore the root is $x=a+1$.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Consider the function defined by $f(x)=x2+6x−77​$ for $x∈R$, $x=−7$, $x=1$.

Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, showing the values of any axes intercepts, the coordinates of any local maxima and minima, and the graphs of any asymptotes. [6]


Next, consider the function $g$ defined by $g(x)=x2+6x−77​$ for $x∈R$, $x>1$.


Show that $g−1(x)=−3+x16x+7​​$. [6]



State the domain of $g−1$. [1]



Now, consider the function $h$ defined by $h(x)=arccos(7x​)$.

Given that $(h∘g)(a)=3π​$, find the value of $a$. Give your answer in the form $p+q2​$ where $p$, $q∈Z$. [7]
list.markScheme:
First we note that the function is undefined for $x=−7$ and $x=1$. Therefore there are two vertical asymptotes, $x=−7$ and $x=1$.
To determine the horizontal asymptote, we examine the behaviour of the function as $x→±∞$.
$x→±∞lim​f(x)=0$
Therefore the horizontal asymptote is $y=0$.
By calculating $f(0)$, we find that the $y$-intercept is $(0,−1)$.
Next, we find the $x$-intercepts by solving the equation $f(x)=0$:
$$$f(x)x2+6x−77​7​=0=0=0​$$$
There are no $x$-intercepts.
Now we need to determine any maxima or minima. To do this, we note that the reciprocal function is
$$$f(x)1​​=7x2+6x−7​=71​(x+7)(x−1)​$$$
The graph of the reciprocal function is a parabola:


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae4ca068-360f-454a-aa85-45ade395c2f5/images/feee365c-c170-4040-9b1c-94787db2210a/AA927a.PNG)


The reciprocal function has a minimum at $(−3,−716​)$ and therefore $f(x)$ has a maximum at $(−3,−167​)$.
Finally, we need to determine the behaviour of the function around the vertical asymptotes. Again, we can use the reciprocal function to determine this.
$∙$ As $x→−7−$, $f(x)1​→0+$. Therefore $f(x)→+∞$.$$
$∙$ As $x→−7+$, $f(x)1​→0−$. Therefore $f(x)→−∞$.$$
$∙$ As $x→1−$, $f(x)1​→0−$. Therefore $f(x)→−∞$. $$
$∙$ As $x→1+$, $f(x)1​→0+$. Therefore $f(x)→+∞$.$$
Therefore the graph of $y=f(x)$ is as follows:


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae4ca068-360f-454a-aa85-45ade395c2f5/images/811951dd-4da1-48ee-bbc1-0cbfc69afa2e/AA927b.PNG)




By switching $x$ and $g(x)$, we create the inverse function:
$$$x​=y2+6y−77​[where y=g−1(x)]​$$$
Given that the domain of $g$ is $x>1$, the range of $g−1$ is $g−1(x)>1$. Therefore $y>1$.
Rearranging to make $y$ the subject, we get
$$$y2+6y−7y2+6y(y+3)2−9(y+3)2y+3y​=x7​=7+x7​=7+x7​[By completing the square]=16+x7​=x16x+7​=x16x+7​​[Since y>1]=−3+x16x+7​​g−1(x)=−3+x16x+7​​​​$$$


We could note that $g(x)=f(x)$ for $x>1$, and therefore using our graph from part (a), the range is $g(x)>0$. Therefore the domain of $g−1(x)$ is $x>0​$


We have
$$$g(a)​=a2+6a−77​​$$$
And
$$$(h∘g)(a)​=arccos(7g(a)​)=arccos(a2+6a−71​)​$$$
Hence
$$$arccos(a2+6a−71​)cos(arccos(a2+6a−71​))a2+6a−71​a2+6a−7a2+6a(a+3)2−9(a+3)2a+3a+3​=3π​=cos(3π​)=21​[since cos(3π​)=21​]=2=9=9[By completing the square]=18=±18​=±32​a=−3+32​​[since a>1]​$$$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
Consider the function defined by $f(x)=(2x−6)ln(x+3)+x$ for
$x∈R$, $x>p$.


Find the value of $p$. [2]



Find an expression for $f′(x)$. [3]



The graph of $y=f(x)$ has no points of
inflexion.

Determine if the graph of $y=f(x)$ is concave down or
concave up over its domain. [3]


The function $g$ is defined by $g(x)=3ln(x+31​)+x$,
for $x∈R$, $x>−3$.


Find an expression for $g′(x)$. [4]



Find the horizontal and vertical asymptotes of
$g′(x)$.[2]



Find the exact value of the minimum of $y=g(x)$.[3]



Solve $f(x)<g(x)$ for $x∈R$, $x>−3$.[5]
list.markScheme:
Due to the natural log term, $x+3>0$. Therefore
$p=−3​$


Differentiating $f$ with respect to $x$, we obtain
$$$f′(x)​=dxd​[(2x−6)ln(x+3)+x]=x+32x−6​+2ln(x+3)+1​​$$$


Differentiating $f′$ with respect to $x$, we obtain
$$$f′′(x)​=dxd​[x+32x−6​+2ln(x+3)+1]=(x+3)2(x+3)(2)−(2x−6)​+x+32​=(x+3)22x+18​​$$$
Hence, over $x>−3$, we have $f′′(x)>0$. Therefore,
$f is concave up​$


Differentiating $g$ with respect to $x$, we obtain
$$$g′(x)​=dxd​[3ln(x+31​)+x]=3(x+3)(−(x+3)21​)+1=x+3−3​+1=x+3x​​​$$$


The denominator of $g′$ is zero when $x=−3$.
Hence,
$the line x=−3 is a vertical asymptote of the graph of y=g′(x)​$
If we take the limit as $x$ tends to $∞$, we have
$$$x→∞lim​g′(x)​=x→∞lim​x+3x​=x→∞lim​1+x3​1​=1​$$$
Hence,
$the line y=1 is a horizontal asymptote of the graph of y=g′(x)​$


From part (d) we obtain a stationary point at $x=0$.
The second derivative of $g$ is
$$$g′′(x)​=dxd​[x+3x​]=(x+3)23​​$$$
Hence, $g′′(x)>0$ which implies that at $x=0$ the function $g$
reaches its minimum. Therefore, the minimum value of $g$ is
$$$g(0)​=3ln(31​)+0=−3ln(3)​​$$$


Using logarithm properties, we get
$$$f(x)(2x−6)ln(x+3)+x(2x−6)ln(x+3)(2x−3)ln(x+3)​<g(x)<3ln(x+31​)+x<−3ln(x+3)<0​$$$
Thus, we have two options
$$$[2x−3<0&ln(x+3)>0][x<1.5&ln(x+3)>0]x<1.5−2<​ or [2x−3>0&ln(x+3)<0] or [x>1.5&ln(x+3)<0]&1<x+3[since ln(x+3)>0 for x>1.5]x<1.5​$$$
Therefore,
$f(x)<g(x)$ over $−2<x<1.5​$
